Title.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the performance of predictors of fluid responsiveness in children across different settings and conditions.

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to either shock or non-shock states.

Participants.evidence: The study included children under 18 years, with physiological responses to intravenous fluid administration assessed. The trial was conducted in both pediatric intensive care units (PICU) and non-PICU settings.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to either shock or non-shock states.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the performance of predictors of fluid responsiveness in children across different settings and conditions.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) for fluid responsiveness, measured over a specified timeframe.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured through sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The meta-analysis revealed poor predictive performance across all tools (AUROC 0.66, 95% CI [0.63, 0.69]).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.
